messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Provably Efficient Offline Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning via Strategy-wise Bonus

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper considers offline multi-agent reinforcement learning. We propose the strategy-wise concentration principle which directly builds a confidence interval for the joint strategy, in contrast to the point-wise concentration principle that builds a confidence interval for each point in the joint action space. For two-player zero-sum Markov games, by exploiting the convexity of the strategy-wise bonus, we propose a computationally efficient algorithm whose sample complexity enjoys a better dependency on the number of actions than the prior methods based on the point-wise bonus. Furthermore, for offline multi-agent general-sum Markov games, based on the strategy-wise bonus and a novel surrogate function, we give the first algorithm whose sample complexity only scales ‚àëi=1mAisuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscriptùê¥ùëñ\sum_{i=1}^{m}A_{i} where Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} is the action size of the iùëñi-th player and mùëöm is the number of players. In sharp contrast, the sample complexity of methods based on the point-wise bonus would scale with the size of the joint action space Œ†i=1m‚ÄãAisuperscriptsubscriptŒ†ùëñ1ùëösubscriptùê¥ùëñ\Pi_{i=1}^{m}A_{i} due to the curse of multiagents. Lastly, all of our algorithms can naturally take a pre-specified strategy class Œ†Œ†\Pi as input and output a strategy that is close to the best strategy in Œ†Œ†\Pi. In this setting, the sample complexity only scales with log‚Å°|Œ†|Œ†\log|\Pi| instead of ‚àëi=1mAisuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscriptùê¥ùëñ\sum_{i=1}^{m}A_{i}.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Off-policy exploitability-evaluation in two-player zero-sum markov games",
        "On the theory of policy gradient methods: Optimality, approximation, and distribution shift",
        "The nonstochastic multiarmed bandit problem",
        "Minimax regret bounds for reinforcement learning",
        "Near-optimal reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "Superhuman ai for multiplayer poker",
        "Convex optimization: Algorithms and complexity",
        "When is offline two-player zero-sum markov game solvable?",
        "Minimax sample complexity for turn-based stochastic game",
        "On the complexity of approximating a nash equilibrium",
        "Gap-dependent bounds for two-player markov games",
        "Soft actor-critic: Off-policy maximum entropy deep reinforcement learning with a stochastic actor",
        "Strategy iteration is strongly polynomial for 2-player turn-based stochastic games with a constant discount factor",
        "Towards general function approximation in zero-sum markov games",
        "Offline decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "V-learning‚Äìa simple, efficient, decentralized algorithm for multiagent rl",
        "Is pessimism provably efficient for offline rl?",
        "Settling the sample complexity of model-based offline reinforcement learning",
        "A sharp analysis of model-based reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "Multi-agent actor-critic for mixed cooperative-competitive environments",
        "Decentralized cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning with exploration",
        "Offline pre-trained multi-agent decision transformer: One big sequence model conquers all starcraftii tasks",
        "Asynchronous methods for deep reinforcement learning",
        "Plan better amid conservatism: Offline multi-agent reinforcement learning with actor rectification",
        "Approximate dynamic programming for two-player zero-sum markov games",
        "Bridging offline reinforcement learning and imitation learning: A tale of pessimism",
        "Nearly horizon-free offline reinforcement learning",
        "Settling the complexity of computing approximate two-player nash equilibria",
        "Safe, multi-agent, reinforcement learning for autonomous driving",
        "Solving discounted stochastic two-player games with near-optimal time and sample complexity",
        "Mastering the game of go without human knowledge",
        "When can we learn general-sum markov games with a large number of players sample-efficiently?",
        "Robustness and sample complexity of model-based marl for general-sum markov games",
        "Finite time bounds for sampling based fitted value iteration",
        "Pessimistic model-based offline reinforcement learning under partial coverage",
        "Learning zero-sum simultaneous-move markov games using function approximation and correlated equilibrium",
        "Batch value-function approximation with only realizability",
        "Bellman-consistent pessimism for offline reinforcement learning",
        "Policy finetuning: Bridging sample-efficient offline and online reinforcement learning",
        "Towards instance-optimal offline reinforcement learning with pessimism",
        "Near-optimal provable uniform convergence in offline policy evaluation for reinforcement learning",
        "Near-optimal offline reinforcement learning via double variance reduction",
        "Provable benefits of actor-critic methods for offline reinforcement learning",
        "Model-based multi-agent rl in zero-sum markov games with near-optimal sample complexity",
        "Multi-agent reinforcement learning: A selective overview of theories and algorithms",
        "Finite-sample analysis for decentralized batch multiagent reinforcement learning with networked agents",
        "Can reinforcement learning find stackelberg-nash equilibria in general-sum markov games with myopic followers?",
        "Pessimistic minimax value iteration: Provably efficient equilibrium learning from offline datasets"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Provably Efficient Offline Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning via Strategy-wise Bonus, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
